facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 81 of 1950 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 81 of 1950.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated 17th March 1944 of Patna High Court by Fazl Ali J. and Beevor J. in F.A. No. 47 of 1942.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from a judgment and decree dated 17th March, 1944, of the High Court of Judicature at Patna  Fazl Ali J. and Beevor J.  in F.A. No. 47 of 1942,

facts.text: High Court appeal arose from decree dated 27th February 1942 of Subordinate Judge of Purnea in Title Mortgage Suit No. 7 of 1940.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of decree dated 27th February, 1942, of the Subordinate Judge of Purnea in Title Mortgage Suit No. 7 of 1940.

facts.text: Appeal originally taken to Judicial Committee on special leave granted by Order in Council dated August 2, 1946, transferred to Supreme Court due to abolition of Privy Council jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, which was originally taken to the JudicialCommittee, on special leave, granted by an Order in Council dated August 2, 1946, number stands transferred to this companyrt by reason of the aboli- tion of the jurisdiction of the Privy Council.

facts.text: Suit commenced by plaintiffs respondents for enforcement of simple mortgage bond by sale of mortgaged property.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants before us are the first party defendants in a suit, companymenced by the plaintiffs respondents, for enforcement of a simple mortgage bond, by sale of the mort- gaged property.

facts.text: Trial Judge (Subordinate Judge) held bond not legally attested, refused sale decree, passed money decree against first party defendants as not time-barred due to payments under section 20 Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge, while deciding all the other issues in favour of the plaintiffs, held on the evi- dence on the record, that the bond sued upon was number legally attested and hence companyld number rank as a mortgage bond. On this finding he refused to make a decree for sale of the mortgaged property in favour of the plaintiffs and passed a money decree, for the amount due on the bond, personally against the defendants first party.

facts.text: Suit instituted more than 6 years after due date but personal claim not time-barred per trial judge due to payments.

anchor.surface_text: According to the Subor- dinate Judge, although the suit was instituted more than 6 years after the date fixed for payment in the bond, yet the claim for personal relief against the mortgagors did number become time-barred by reason of the fact that there were several payments made by the defendants towards the satis- faction of the debt,

facts.text: Defendants appealed to Patna High Court, no appeal or cross-objection by plaintiffs against refusal of sale decree.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision an appeal was taken by the defendants mortgagors to the High Court of Patna, but numberappeal or ,cross-objection was filed by the plaintiffs against the refusal of the trial Court to make an order for sale of the mortgaged property in their favour.

facts.text: Patna High Court held bond duly attested, effective as mortgage, suit within time, but affirmed money decree as no appeal/cross-objection by plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on hearing the appeal came to the companyclusion that the bond in suit was duly attested and was effective and enforceable as a mortgage bond, and that the view taken by the trial companyrt on the question of attestation companyld number be sustained on the evidence on the record. ... The learned Judges held, however, that as the plaintiffs had number preferred any appeal or cross objection ... The result was that the decree made by the trial Judge was affirmed.

facts.text: Mortgage bond dated 8th April 1927, executants signed on 12th April 1927, registered on 12th April 1927.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgage bond is dated the 8th of April, 1927, but it is numberlonger disputed that the executants put their signatures to the document on the 12th of April fol- lowing, and admittedly it was registered on the latter date.

facts.text: Due date in mortgage bond is 6th March 1928.

anchor.surface_text: The due date, as given in the mortgage, is the 6th of March, 1928.

facts.text: Suit instituted on 4th March 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was instituted on 4th of March, 1940,

facts.text: Plaintiffs claimed eight payments by defendants: Rs.300 on 21 Jan 1928, Rs.75 on 5 Jun 1929, Rs.? on 8 Mar 1931, on 3 Apr 1931, two in May 1932, 25 Jul 1934, 15 May 1936, total Rs.780-9-0.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs stated specifically in their plaint that the defendants made eight payments in all, aggregating to a sum of Rs. 780-9-0, ... The first payment which was of a sum of Rs. 300 was made on 21st January, 1928, ... second ... 5th of June, 1929. The third ... 8th of March, 193l, ... fourth ... 3rd April, 1931. the fifth and the sixth ... May, 1932, the seventh ... 25th July, 1934, and the last ... 15th of May, 1936.

facts.text: Defendants 1 to 3 admitted in written statement para 15 the payments specified in plaint were made, but claimed additional payments.

anchor.surface_text: What the Subordinate Judge relied upon, is the admission companytained in paragraph 15 of the written statement filed on behalf of defendants 1 to 3 in the present suit where these defendants admitted number only that the payments specified in the plaint were actually made on the respective dates but asserted that there were other payments besides these,

facts.text: Supreme Court held no written acknowledgment of payments prior to suit institution, so personal money decree barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: This being the position, the suit treated as one for obtaining a money decree against the defendants must be held to be barred by limitation at the date on which it was instituted and the companyrts below companysequently were number justified in giving the plaintiffs a money decree in this suit.

facts.text: Mortgage bond written and engrossed at plaintiffs' house in village Chakla Maulanagur on 21st Chaitra 1334 Fasli corresponding to 8th April 1927.

anchor.surface_text: the evidence shows that the mortgage bond was written and engrossed at the plaintiffs house at village Chakla Maulanagur and the date which the document bears is 21st Chaitra 1334 Fasli companyresponding to 8th April, 1027.

facts.text: Four attesting witnesses: Sunderlal, Matukdhari Prasad, Dwarka Prasad, Nanak Prasad (scribe), all residents of Chakla Maulanagur.

anchor.surface_text: There are four attesting witnesses whose names appear in the deed, to wit, Sunderlal, Matukdhari Prasad, Dwarka Prasad and Nanak Prasad the last named person being also the scribe of the document --and all of them were residents of Chakla Maulanagur which is the place of resi- dence of the mortgagees.

facts.text: Mortgagors inhabitants of village Chandpur.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgagors, on the other hand, are inhabitants of a different village, namely, Chand- pur.

facts.text: Attesting witnesses Sunderlal (PW1) and Matukdhari Prasad testified bond written, signed by executants, attested same day at plaintiffs' house.

anchor.surface_text: Sunderlal, who is P.W. 1, states ... I signed the bond at the plaintiffs house, as did the attesting witnesses. The attestation of the bond was on the same day that it was written. The other attesting witness, Matukdhari Prasad, ... The bond was written, signed by the executants and attested by the wit- nesses on the same date.

facts.text: Executants signed document on 12th April 1927, presented for registration same day at Katihar.

anchor.surface_text: The document shows that all the three executants put their signatures to it on 12th of April, 1927, and on the same day it was presented for registration before the Regis- tering Officer at Katihar.

facts.text: Supreme Court found attestation defective as witnesses signed before execution by executants.

anchor.surface_text: As the document was written on the 8th but actually executed on the 12th, the Subordinate Judge was of opinion that the attesting witnesses must have signed the deed before it was executed land this was numberattestation in the eye of law.

facts.text: Defendant No.1 Sant Lall testified executants signed at Katihar, not at plaintiffs' village.

anchor.surface_text: He was asked as to whether the document was executed at the plaintiffs village or at Katihar, where it was taken for registration. The witness persisted in saying that he and the other executants put their signatures number at the place of the plaintiffs but at Katihar

issues.text: whether the trial Judge was right in holding that the payments made by the defendants satisfied the requirements of section 20 of the Limitation Act and were hence available to the plaintiffs for the purpose of extending the period of limitation

anchor.surface_text: The position, therefore, is that if the bond in the present case cannot be treated as a mortgage bond and the only relief which the plaintiffs can claim is one for recovery of money against the defendants personally, the suit must be deemed to be barred, as it was instituted beyond 6 years from the due date of payment unless limitation is saved by reason of the payments under section 20 of the Limitation Act. This leads us to enquire as to whether the trial Judge was right in holding that the payments made by the defendants satisfied the requirements of section 20 of the Limitation Act and were hence available to the plaintiffs for the purpose of extending the period of limitation within which the suit should otherwise have been brought.

issues.text: The short point for our consideration is whether the view taken by the Subordinate Judge is correct

anchor.surface_text: What the Subordinate Judge relied upon, is the admission contained in paragraph 15 of the written statement filed on behalf of defendants 1 to 3 in the present suit where these defendants admitted not only that the payments specified in the plaint were actually made on the respective dates but asserted that there were other payments besides these, which reduced the debt still further and for which the plaintiffs did not give any credit to the defendants. In the opinion of the Subordinate Judge as the written statement was signed by these defendants, it would fulfil all the requirements of a signed acknowledgment as is contemplated by the proviso to section 20. The short point for our consideration is whether the view taken by the Subordinate Judge is correct ?

issues.text: Whether the finding of the High Court on the question of attestation is a correct and proper finding on the evidence adduced in this case

anchor.surface_text: The question now is whether we can pass a mortgage decree in favour of the plaintiffs on the basis of the finding of the High Court that the bond was properly attested and it is not disputed that no question of limitation would in that case arise. To decide this question there are two points which require consideration -- Whether the finding of the High Court on the question of attestation is a correct and proper finding on the evidence adduced in this case ?

issues.text: whether the facts of the plaintiffs not having preferred an appeal or cross-objection against that part of the judgment of the trial Judge which refused them a mortgage decree, stands in the way of their claiming any relief other than what was given to them by the trial Judge

anchor.surface_text: Whether the finding of the High Court on the question of attestation is a correct and proper finding on the evidence adduced in this case ? If it is so, whether the facts of the plaintiffs not having preferred an appeal or cross-objection against that part of the judgment of the trial Judge which refused them a mortgage decree, stands in the way of their claiming any relief other than what was given to them by the trial Judge ?

issues.text: even if the High Court was right in holding that the bond in suit was effective as a mortgage bond and the suit could be treated as one for enforcement of a mortgage, no decree for money could be passed against the defendants personally, unless the suit was instituted within the period prescribed by Article 116 of the Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: Mr. De, who appeared in support of the appeal, has contended in the first place that even if the High Court was right in holding that the bond in suit was effective as a mortgage bond and the suit could be treated as one for enforcement of a mortgage, no decree for money could be passed against the defendants personally, unless the suit was instituted within the period prescribed by Article 116 of the Limitation Act.

arguments.claim: Written statement admission fulfills requirements of signed acknowledgment under proviso to section 20 Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: What the Subordinate Judge relied upon, is the admission companytained in paragraph 15 of the written statement filed on behalf of defendants 1 to 3 in the present suit where these defendants admitted number only that the payments specified in the plaint were actually made on the respective dates but asserted that there were other payments besides these,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ation, Order 7, Rule 6, of the Civil Procedure Code makes it his duty to state specifically in the plaint the grounds of exemption allowed by the Limi

arguments.court_reasoning: Acknowledgment must exist prior to suit institution

arguments.claim: For section 20, payment extends limitation but requires written acknowledgment by payer; acknowledgment need not be within limitation period

anchor.surface_text: It would be clear, we think, from the language of section 20 of the Limitation Act that to attract its operation two companyditions are essential first, the payment must be made within the prescribed period of limitation and secondly, it must be acknowledged by some form of writing either in the handwriting of the payer himself or signed by him.

arguments.claim: Acknowledgment under section 20 must be in existence prior to institution of suit

anchor.surface_text: But while it is number necessary that the written acknowl- edgment should be made prior to the expiry of the period of limitation, it is, in our opinion, essential that such acknowledgment, whether made before or after the period of limitation, must be in existence prior to the institution of the suit.

arguments.claim: Suit time-barred if no prior acknowledgment; courts below wrong to grant money decree

anchor.surface_text: This being the position, the suit treated as one for obtaining a money decree against the defendants must be held to be barred by limitation at the date on which it was instituted and the companyrts below companysequently were number justified in giving the plaintiffs a money decree in this suit.

arguments.claim: Attestation defective as witnesses signed before executants executed on 12th April

anchor.surface_text: As the document was written on the 8th but actually executed on the 12th, the Subordinate Judge was of opinion that the attesting witnesses must have signed the deed before it was executed land this was numberattestation in the eye of law.

arguments.claim: High Court erred in interpreting witnesses' testimony on 'written' to include execution

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, on the other hand, has held that the vernacular equivalent of the word written as used by the attesting witnesses might mean execution as well and the Subordinate Judge, who was number familiar with the language of the witnesses might have companymitted the mistake of taking the word written in the sense of mere engrossing or scribing of the deed,

holdings.text: The suit treated as one for obtaining a money decree against the defendants must be held to be barred by limitation at the date on which it was instituted and the courts below consequently were not justified in giving the plaintiffs a money decree in this suit.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No written signed acknowledgment of payments existed prior to suit institution; limitation determined at plaint date per s3 Limitation Act; written statement admission post-suit insufficient.

holdings.text: It is essential that such acknowledgment, whether made before or after the period of limitation, must be in existence prior to the institution of the suit.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit status fixed at plaint filing; plaintiff must allege existing facts for exemption under O7 R6 CPC and s3 Limitation Act; post-plaint facts cannot revive barred action.

holdings.text: The finding of the High Court on the question of attestation is not a correct and proper finding on the evidence adduced in this case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows document written and attested by witnesses on 8th April at plaintiffs' house; executants signed on 12th April at Katihar before registration; witnesses signed before execution.

holdings.text: The attesting witnesses must have signed the deed before it was executed and this was not attestation in the eye of law.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Attesting witnesses testified to signing same day as written (8th); execution signatures dated 12th at distant registration office; trial judge's view correct, High Court misinterpreted vernacular testimony.

holdings.text: If the bond cannot be treated as a mortgage bond... the suit must be deemed to be barred, as it was instituted beyond 6 years from the due date of payment unless limitation is saved by reason of the payments under section 20.

anchor.surface_text: The position, therefore, is that if the bond in the present case cannot be treated as a mortgage bond and the only relief which the plaintiffs can claim is one for recovery of money against the defendants personally, the suit must be deemed to be barred, as it was instituted beyond 6 years from the due date of payment unless limitation is saved by reason of the payments under section 20 of the Limitation Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Registered bond personal recovery governed by Art 116 (6 years from due date); framing as mortgage does not extend personal decree limitation.
